stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the Raphael the Raven boss fight in Course 13. The main activities included debugging a hitbox bug, implementing planetary gravity mechanics for the moon arena, designing and balancing the boss's attack patterns, and brainstorming a way for the player to complete the level after the fight. A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to problem-solving the post-fight sequence, ultimately simplifying it by having the star appear on the moon itself.
level: Raphael the Raven Boss Fight (Moon Arena)

development_findings.summary: A bug where a boss attack was not registering was traced back to the boss's model being scaled down to the point that its hitbox had a size of zero.
development_findings.quote: The scale of Raphael Raven was too small. He was scaling down so far that his hitbox was 0.

development_findings.summary: Kaze abandoned the idea of using a pipe for the player to return from the moon boss fight due to both the technical complexity of rotating it correctly on a spherical surface and its lack of narrative sense.
development_findings.quote: I think the pipe sucks. It sucks programming wise. And it's also not really very visually clear. Why that would happen.

development_findings.summary: The final design for the post-boss sequence is for the star to spawn directly on the moon, which the player collects there, simplifying the design and avoiding a complex return sequence.
Kaze implemented a dynamic difficulty system for the boss fight where the boss slows down more over time, ensuring all players can eventually win.
development_findings.quote: It's very hard to find the correct velocity there, because if you set it to 0, the fight is laughably easy, and if you set it like what I have right now, it's a little too hard.

development_findings.summary: The game's hub world is planned to be a large version of Yoshi's Island, inspired by the Yoshi's Tropical Island board from Mario Party, where players will use coins to fund projects like building bridges to enable progression.
development_findings.quote: The hub world is gonna be Yoshi's Island, of course. You know the Maori Party Board? Yoshi's Tropical Island, where there's fruits everywhere? I want it like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using quaternions and matrix transformations to handle the planetary gravity and fix objects like the star and eggs to the surface of the moon.
Kaze is struggling with creating a cinematic cutscene for the transition to the moon, iterating on camera positioning and movement curves to make it visually appealing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with pressure from the community regarding the game's release date and contradictory feedback on its difficulty.
context_findings.quote: You know what the most fucked up part about being a famous romaker is? When people harass me about the release date.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he is experiencing significant mental stress due to unspecified 'bureaucracy', an external pressure affecting him during development.
context_findings.quote: I'm in mental pain because of bureaucracy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to increase his YouTube video output, focusing on accessible topics about SM64 mechanics, as a way to generate more income for his family, indicating a financial motivation influencing his work.
context_findings.quote: I'm thinking I will just pump out a lot of videos... to make more money for my family.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal philosophy that physical health is connected to mental well-being, mentioning that he works out.
context_findings.quote: You gotta take care of your body. If you wanna take care of your mind.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design philosophy against dynamic difficulty that scales to player health, believing it invalidates player progression. He prefers time-based difficulty scaling to ensure a challenge is eventually surmountable for all players.
context_findings.quote: You know how when you play games and there's like a level system... and then the enemies scale to your own level and it's like leveling makes no sense anymore? That's how I feel about scaling it by health. That's why I want to scale it by time.

biobak.summary: Kaze is excited about Biobak's potential contribution to the boss fight's visuals, specifically envisioning a rotating background to enhance the scene.
biobak.quote: Dude, Biobak, you can make this fight look so fucking cool with the background. Imagine the whole background here just rotating around.

biobak.summary: Kaze implemented a specific visual behavior for the boss based on a request or idea from Biobak.
biobak.quote: I made him get his color only after he does the stomp so that the effect that you want in Biobak can be made.

biobak.summary: Kaze identifies a potential conflict between two different visual ideas proposed by Biobak for the intro cutscene, indicating an ongoing creative discussion.
biobak.quote: But wait. That's completely incompatible with the other idea. You had Biomex. How is he going to obstruct the moon if we do this?

zeina.summary: Zeina created the animation for the explosive meteor attack, which Kaze then tweaked for implementation.
zeina.quote: I think Zeina made it. I just made some small changes to make sure it works better here.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for creating the necessary animations for the Raphael the Raven boss fight.
zeina.quote: Yeah, Zeina is currently working on all the animations we need vfx sfx and camera shakes and stuff like that.

zeina.summary: At the end of the stream, Kaze confirmed he had received the new animations from Zeina but would implement them in a future session.

key_stories.title: Balancing the Raphael the Raven Boss Fight
key_stories.summary: Kaze found his own boss fight too hard and decided to implement a dynamic difficulty system. Rejecting health-based scaling, he made the boss easier over time, ensuring all players could eventually win while preserving the initial challenge.
key_stories.challenge: The Raphael the Raven boss fight was too difficult for a player to consistently beat, even for Kaze himself.
key_stories.process: Kaze first identified that making the boss stop completely made the fight too easy. He then decided to scale the boss's slowdown period based on time elapsed, rather than player health, to maintain a sense of accomplishment. He coded this logic and tested it to find a reasonable balance.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a dynamic difficulty system. The boss now slows down for longer periods as the fight progresses, ensuring that any player can eventually defeat it without making the fight trivial from the start.
key_stories.key_quote: If I'm struggling this much, it's way too difficult.

key_stories.title: Designing the Return Trip from the Moon
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a way for Mario to get back from the moon boss arena. After struggling with the complex math of spawning a correctly-oriented pipe and rejecting other ideas, he simplified the problem by deciding the star would just appear on the moon, eliminating the need for a return trip.
key_stories.challenge: After defeating the boss on the moon, there was no clear, technically simple, or narratively logical way for Mario to return to the main level.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to program a pipe that would appear on the moon's surface but struggled with the rotational math. He considered other ideas like a trampoline but rejected them for being too derivative of Mario Galaxy. He ultimately chose the simplest solution: just put the star on the moon.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to have the star appear directly on the moon. This eliminated the need for a return journey, simplifying the programming significantly and providing a clean end to the level segment.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the pipe sucks. It sucks programming wise. And it's also not really very visually clear. Why that would happen.

key_stories.title: The Zero-Size Hitbox Bug
key_stories.summary: The boss's meteor attack suddenly stopped working. Through a process of elimination, Kaze discovered that his code was scaling the boss model down so much that its hitbox size became zero, making it impossible to hit. He fixed the scaling issue, resolving the bug.
key_stories.challenge: A critical bug prevented the boss's meteor attack from damaging the boss, halting development of the fight.
key_stories.process: Kaze systematically debugged the issue. He first printed the boss's position, then checked the distance calculation. He eventually hypothesized that the issue was related to the boss's scale, which he had recently changed. He confirmed the hitbox size was becoming zero and corrected the code.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze fixed the bug by correcting the scaling logic, ensuring the hitbox remained active. This allowed him to resume balancing and developing the rest of the boss fight.
key_stories.key_quote: The scale of Raphael Raven was too small. He was scaling down so far that his hitbox was 0.
